Name: Requiring the department of health and mental hygiene to measure pollutants near potential pollution hotspots in community air quality surveys.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to requiring the department of health and mental hygiene to measure pollutants near potential pollution hotspots in community air quality surveys

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council

Summary: This bill would require the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene (DOHMH) to include in its annual community air quality survey pollution measurements for at least 50 “potential pollution hotspots,” locations in close proximity to a source that is likely to significantly increase the concentrations of pollutants in its immediate vicinity.

Be it enacted by the Council as follows:\ulnone\par

\pard\ltrpar\fi720\sl480\slmult1\qj Section 1. Subdivisions a and b of section 17-125 of the administrative code of the city New York, as added by local law number 103 for the year 2015, are amended to read as follows:\par
\cf1 a. For [the] purposes of this section, \ul the following terms have the following meanings:\par
Pollutants. The term\ulnone  "pollutants" means particulate matter that is less than 2.5 micrometers in diameter, nitrogen dioxide, nitric oxide, sulfur dioxide and ground-level ozone.\par
\ul Potential pollution hotspot. The term \ldblquote potential pollution hotspot\rdblquote  means a location in close proximity to a source that is likely to significantly increase the concentrations of pollutants in its immediate vicinity.\cf0\par
\cf1\ulnone b. The department shall conduct a community air quality survey on an annual basis. Such survey shall:\par
1. Measure pollutants at street-level at monitoring sites across the city of New York over every season of the year, selected to ensure that the number of monitoring sites provides adequate information to assess the range of common emissions sources and neighborhood pollutant concentrations across the city, as determined by the department. \ul At least 50 of such monitoring sites shall be located at potential pollution hotspots.\ulnone  At the discretion of the department, data on ozone may be measured in the summer months only and data on sulfur dioxide may be measured in the winter months only;\par
2. Determine whether and how concentrations of pollutants near monitor sites vary across the city and the relationship, if any, of such concentrations to local traffic, building emissions and other factors;\par
3. Identify the major local sources of pollutants that contribute to local variation in the concentrations thereof;\par
4. Identify patterns of pollutants by geographic area, by source, and by season or time of year;\ul  \par
\ulnone 5. Produce maps indicating the varying concentration levels of pollutants across neighborhoods, \ul at potential pollution hotspots,\ulnone  and by pollutant;\par
6. Write an annual report summarizing the results of the activities described in paragraphs [one] \ul 1\ulnone  through [five] \ul 5\ulnone  of this subdivision;\par
7. Include in such report the findings of any completed or ongoing health surveillance or research studies using community air quality survey data to estimate population exposure to pollutants; and\par
8. Describe in the report the scientific methodology used to select monitor locations for measuring pollutants\ul , including the scientific methodology used to select potential pollution hotspots,\ulnone  and \ul the scientific methodology used \ulnone for studying variations in pollutant concentrations.\cf0\ul\par
\ulnone\'a7 2. \cf1 This local law takes effect 120 days after it becomes law.\par
